reviewText:
A wonderful little Visual Novel based on the beloved turn-of-the-century novel in which you follow Sara, a quiet, imaginative, and kind young lady raised in India and sent away to England for schooling. The game features some light stat-raising elements and very light decision making, but it is primarily a linear story with optional events. In the second half of the game, the story divides into 6 distinct routes, each leading to a unique ending. The avaliblity of the routes depends on your actions in the first half of the story, so multiple playthroughs of the first act are required to see all the routes; fortunately, the game includes to option to skip through already-viewed scenes.

The writing is thoroughly enjoyable and adorable. Some of the routes feature light romantic elements, but not all of them do; you will find a range of different relationships from good friends, to nuturing parental figure, to sweetly romantic.

Overall, a highly recommended VN, particularly if you're ok with something lighter on gameplay and focusing on narrative. If you're looking for a Princess Maker-style stat raiser, on the other hand, this one might not be for you.

Note: This game was originally purchased directly from the developer and this review was posted immediately following the pre-Steam release beta period, so hours played might not line up with the actual length of this game.

reviewText:
EDIT: Oops, forgot to mention that my really short gameplay time is due to the fact that I played the beta quite a bit back before this game released on steam or even on their website.

The best and shortest way I can describe this game is that it is VERY precious. Might be the most precious game I've played.

Art & MusicYou only need to look at the screenshots of the game to see that it has really beautiful art, with well-drawn backgrounds and character portraits that work together really well. The specific aspect that bumps this up though are CGs. They look amazing blown up on my widescreen monitor where all the little details can be easily pointed out. It must also be said that the same goes for the rest of the game. At least on my machine, it ran full widescreen with no indication of any stretched images, which for some reason is not as common as I would like in other works of the same genre. This game aced this part. I'm not really very good at describing music, but I have to say that this one tugged at my heartstrings way too often (to the point of abuse really). It fits the individual moments perfectly with every sense of dread, sadness, glee, or just plain heartwarming moments that make you go d'awwww" while holding back tears. That won't work though

reviewText:
If you know the story of Sara Crewe, you know most of what's going to happen. The visual novel aspect is about developing relationships with the secondary characters. You develop stats based on what you choose to do with your free time and trigger scenes with the other girls if your stats meet certain requirements. There isn't enough time to get through everyone's scenes but I've gotten through three girls' scenes in a single playthrough. In Act II you have to pick one girl to have scenes with but if you save at the beginning of Act II you can avoid repeating Act I for everyone.

As any shoujo-ai fan will tell you, Lily" being in the title means there's gonna be some girl-love. It's very mild. Some cuddling and only one girl actually pushes past "romantic friendship" into "schoolgirl lesbian" territory.

I think this game is suitable for any little girls who can read well enough. But be prepared to discuss death
hoursPlayed: and romance between girls as necessary.\n\nBecause everyone seems to ask: No

reviewText: Finished the last route in A Little Lily Princess
date:
which is another amazing game from Hanako Games (under the name Hanabira).

As per usual with games from Hanako, you play a young girl, in this case Sara Crewe, who performs activities every week to increase a number of skills (such as Sympathy or Grace). With these skill increases, you unlock different routes and scenes for each of the six potential girls that you can romance (which is where A Little Lily Princess" differs from Hanako's acclaimed "Long Live the Queen").

You will
recommended: through these interactions (as well as the weekly slice
voteText: learn about these characters. You have the fire-haired Jessie
helpfulPercent: a ballerina with an eye for curiosity; Lavinia
votesHelpful: the haughty model student at Miss Minchin's Seminary; Lottie
votesTotal: the little girl who knows how to throw a tantrum; Ermengarde
votesFunny: the soft country girl who makes up her lack of wit with her heart of gold; Marriette
commentsCount: Sara's personal maid from France; and Becky

You have been warned.\n\nGoing back to the game, I cannot recommend it enough. You may ask me a favourite route, and I will simply chuckle and say All of them!" Each one of these girls has their own story

column27: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A wonderful little gem without a doubt. I really loved every moment of this precious visual novel. I felt like I was sharing the happy, sad, joyous and tragic moments with Sara and the other girls.

The writing is really well done, all the characters are interesting and loveable (except those that aren't loveable, yes, I'm seeing to you, Miss Minchin). And truth to be told, several times while playing my eyes became misty.
The art is lovely, with a cute character design, adorable chibis and beautiful CG. The latter are just breath taking. Wonderful work.
And the music. Is just great. Really enhances the experience. In the climax of the story, the music is used perfectly, give me goosebumps.

Finally, the routes, are all wonderful. Most are romantic. Others more friendship. Some, depends if you squint or not while  playing. But all are fantastic. I love all of them.

In conclusion, a wonderful game which carried me for eighteen hours (six of them played on the beta, more or less) to the Victorian England, and to the lives of those wonderful girls.
My only complain is that I just want more. But, of course, that is me being greedy. I can't have enough cute lovely Victorian yuri.

reviewText:
The writing is beautiful, and the artwork is lovely too. The main storyline is written in such a way as to make Sara highly sympathetic but not sickeningly angelic. The individual storylines are very well-written and provide some fascinating insights into the characters.

My only criticism is that there aren't very many decisions to be made, unlike the other Hanako game I've played, Long Live The Queen. But that would be a consequence of following the plot of A Little Princess. I like games with more decision-making, and the activity planning seemed a little pointless in this game.

That's about all, though. Emotionally, this game was very satisfying, and I don't mind admitting how often I cried while playing it. I heartily recommend it to anyone who enjoys moving, emotional narratives.

reviewText: This was a rather unique experience for me. I've played visual novels before, and I had a cursory knowledge of the source material going in.\n\nIn short, this is a visual novel retelling of the story A Little Princess." It takes a few liberties with the source material such as Miss Minchin's sister being completely absent
date: and they created one character wholecloth.\n\nBeing a visual novel
recommended: there's really not much that you can expect from the game. The interface is clean
hoursPlayed: the mechanics are explained well enough
voteText: though the RNG element can make it frustrating if you're shooting for a specific ending. Jessie's route
votesHelpful: requires a high number of high count skills
votesTotal: while characters like Mariette and Becky tend to have lower costs. It also completely goes out the window in the second have of the game
votesFunny: where you can completely cheese the system.\n\nHow you feel about this game's plot will depend greatly on how you feel about the source material. If you don't like Victorian era novels with social commentary that inflict misfortunate on characters that don't deserve it
commentsCount: you probably won't like it.\n\nI won't go into TOO much detail on the plot
column16: but suffice to say the game takes a turn at the halfway point
column17: and the mechanics do so as well.\n\nThat said I actually like it a bit BETTER than the source material. The characters are much more fleshed out and less one-dimensional
column19: who in the novel were "a rich bully and her hanger-on." Lavinia becomes a much more complicated character
column20: and Jessie actually GETS a character.\n\nAbout the only disappointment is that some of the stories needed a bit more time to develop. Jessie and Mariette's work out fine
column21: but Lavinia probably could have used a few extra scenes since she undergoes the most drastic change.\n\nAlso there's a lack of a "golden ending
column22:
you have to pick ONE path to the end, and it's more of a sidestory. The game ends the same way the book does, though Sara may get one more additional companion if she chooses someone other than Mariette or Becky (they go with her no matter what).

And, uh, that brings me to the last point. The sorta elephant in the room: I haven't finished ALL the routes, only half, but 2/3 of those are effectively lesbian love stories. Naturally I'd imagine the total number of lesbians would be 4 out of the 6, as Mariette's too old and Lottie's too young, but I've been wrong before. Safe to say, though, Jessie's definitely a lesbian in this version, and Lavinia's probably Sara-sexual. Though given Sara's personality, it could just be them attracted to HER specifically.

Because...maybe it's just because my experience with the source material is primarily the film adaptations (where the dad is kept alive. Spoiler alert for a 110 year old book: He really IS dead in the novel) and maybe it's the perspective and choice given to you, the player...but Sara feels a little stronger here.

Anyway, in short, I recommend this VN. It's the type of thing I'd like to see more of: retellings of classic stories that give the player more control over events. It would certainly help mitigate possible plotholes.

reviewText:
I overall enjoy this game very much. So I shall give a review for all people pondering to buy this game.
(Note: I have not yet finished the game so I cannot give a full review as of now.)

Art and Appearence The art style is a mix of Victorian and Anime/Manga. I completely enjoy the art style and find it as a relaxing overlook to the more serious moments in game. The appearence of the game is calming. My only problem with it is the backrounds are a bit too whimsical for my taste. (Again, this is my personal prefrence. So, if you enjoy it I can understand. I just think it dosen't fit the tone of the game.)

Music and Sounds The music is nice piano music that I like. (If you don't like classical you won't like this music.) Along with other orchestral music. It fits the Victorian scene, if you ask me. I personaly like it. (After playing for a while it does get a bit overused.)

Characters Some are quite bland but, most are interesting and you can connect with them. My personal favorite is Lottie. (SHE'S CUTE... OKAY. I LIKE CUTE THINGS...) But, in all seriousness I realy like the characters and I think the studio did a good job.

Story IF YOU READ THE LITTLE PRINCESS AND LIKED IT YOU WILL LOVE THIS. LIKE SERIOUSLY. LOVE IT.
The story is an adapted version of The Little Princess. I think (so far) it's been preaty close to the real book. (Without copying of course) I like the story. (Mostly because I liked The Little Princess.)

Overall Rating 8/10 Would reccomend and I suggest if you like reading you'll love this.

reviewText:
This is a very well written visual novel game with (light) yuri theme set in the Victorian Era.  All the principal characters are portrayed in depth, with realistic personalities and motivations of their own.  I also found the protagonist, Sara Crewe, a highly sympathetic character.  The overall story is based on an older literary work which I have not read, but I feel that the presentation in this game is excellent.  The sprites and CGs are AWESOME as well.

I love this game, I enjoyed all the endings, and I highly recommended it to anyone interested in soft yuri VNs, or someone who enjoys literature or stories with Victorian background.

There is one very minor personal gripe, which does not distract much from my enjoyment of the game but I thought I would point it out here.  I feel that the life simulator portion of the game does not add much value at all to the gaming experience here, and feels more like a waste of time for me, but it is just my personal opinion of course.

All in all though, I LOVE this game and I think it is worth every penny!

reviewText: I've just finished Jessie's route, and I'm almost in tears (sad stuff + music always get me). I haven't read the original novel so I can't really comment on the game as an adaptation, but the way the story was paced was excellent. I must also praise the way Jessie's sexuality was portrayed and the brief mention of suicide - very well-done.\nWonderful characterisation, lovely art, great use of music (played my emotions like a fiddle). Overall an engaging and well-polished visual novel. Highly recommend it to fans of classic literature and visual novels.

reviewText:
This is an adorable little Visual Novel and stat builder.
The stat building part is easy to get the hang of and, while it can be frustrating at times, it is rather fun to use.
The VN is very well written and sympathy can be felt for the main character and companions. While it does have Yuri in it, its very well written and adds to the games charm.
Prepare for sobs and tears though, as the story is often gut wrenching in its sorrow and will have you bawling like a nancy.
